R: @kennknowles 
R: @lukecwik

re @bjchambers

> do we have a test that takes all the kinds of display data and writes them to JSON and looks at the details of that encoding (eg., whether a number is written as a number or a string, etc.)?

Yes, this exists; check out [`DataflowPipelineTranslatorTest#testStepDisplayData()`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/9793fa2c860279b8c90254260c87e5665b000254/sdks/java/core/src/test/java/com/google/cloud/dataflow/sdk/runners/DataflowPipelineTranslatorTest.java#L807).

I'd propose editing the CL description. Based on my reading, the main changes are:
1. Don't drop incoming elements based on the triggers being closed in their assigned windows.
2. Move inspection of finished bits (and associated dropping of elements based on their merge-result windows) to after pre-fetching.
3. Clear finished bits when a window is merged away (I think this may be the leak you were mentioning).

Can we change/simplify any behavior of GC based on (3)? Any high-level changes that I missed?

Updated description.
I'd already exploited the 'clean up state as we merge' behavior of triggers to minimize unnecessary state clearing in ReduceFnRunner. Now we just do it correctly :-)

Ok, I'll save this one for just the source, and will send in pub/sub client and sink as sep prs.
Presumably we don't want this as is? All it does is add a dep but make no action. (FWICT)
Yes, I'd take this as is (for now). This allows us to invoke the plugin's goals easily, and can make it work without affecting everyone's build process.
I see. In that case, LGTM

re: testStepDisplayData: It looks like that tests that the constructed `Map`s are equal, rather than the underlying JSON. Depending on the requirements of consumers, it may be good to actually test that the JSON is exactly the same (since some parsers may be more/less strict about spaces, etc.). Definitely not required in this PR though.

We want two properties:
- [closed is stable predicate] once a trigger closes, no element will be emitted for that window.
- [bundling invariance] merging of closed and unclosed windows should not depend on bundling

So I think we need to check for closed triggers both pre- and post-merging.

Will do that tomorrow, though at this point making triggers unclosable sure looks appealing.

LGTM. I am sad that the `ReduceFnRunner` continues to be the nexus of all logic, but this is definitely a major semantic improvement in addition to the bugs addressed.

Sorry, missed the last bit about it being unfinished. I think we have a few good stories to proceed with improving finished state and merging.

Trigger progression, hence "closing", fundamentally depends on bundling. I agree with you and this implies that windows with a finished trigger must still be eligible for merge, like a black hole.

R: @bjchambers

Re: Travis vs Jenkins I don't care so much in this case. It should be fast, so it does not slow down code review waiting for results. If Jenkins is faster, then it is definitely the best choice.

But I have a different stance on the meta-issue:
1. Travis (or equivalent - even our own `.jenkins.sh`) piggybacks on our existing processes perfectly.
   - Process: Code review of the configuration changes. This implies higher quality results and more transparency about when and why changes occur.
   - Permissions: Anyone can propose a change in a PR, and any committer can accept it.
   - Tools: Text editor, git. And the UI, while less powerful overall, is easier for newcomers.
2. Travis has good integrations with lots of services. For example, you can use coveralls without a repo token :-)
3. Travis is trivial to configure.

Jenkins has capabilities that Travis does not have:
1. It has a nice test result UI. This is the only reason I can think of to run unit tests there.
2. You can configure a build that won't just obey the instructions in a PR, so it can do more sensitive things or be very expensive to run. (integration tests, submit queue)
3. Lots of plugins.
4. (Hopefully) lower latency for uploading coverage.

These are compelling. We should use Jenkins for these things. But I don't see a strong reason to use it for more than that, especially since there are major downsides - no source control of config, more complex config, having to issue tickets to infra for some changes, silent back-channel changes, no review of config changes, no presubmit of config changes, no ability to synchronously alter config and code, ...

For now, I'd be happy to merge PRs and get immediate benefit from Travis until our Jenkins config is offering equivalent capabilities. Perhaps it will be quite soon, but the cost is zero either way.

Love it. I did some brief checking into comparable libraries.
- [lombok](https://projectlombok.org/): mutates the current class to add getters and setters. This is actually forbidden for annotation processors as I understand them, so I guess Lombok uses more fragile hooks to accomplish it. I agree with criticism that this is slightly more "magical", in a bad way.
- [immutables](https://immutables.github.io/): very similar. They emphasize builders, which [autovalue can also provide](https://github.com/google/auto/blob/master/value/userguide/builders.md). Immutables works with interfaces, which seems nice.
- [FreeBuilder](http://freebuilder.inferred.org/) (also originating from Google) is a subset of AutoValue and seems a lower vitality project.

I am torn between my bias towards Google technology and the (admittedly modest) bonus of interface support in Immutables. Immutables also has some built-in support for Java standard lib classes - can you dig into the differences there?
BTW examining the latency, Jenkins is much much lower latency so we should go with Jenkins for this. Travis in the meantime.
Issue in question https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-182
The breakage is unrelated and caused by a recent commit https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/commit/22fd12061ebb6de921cd6fc22d6eb6e937f9a47d
